posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Almost one week with the RG351v (ARKos). Thoughts so far:

- Battery reading is pretty inaccurate. Sometimes you turn it off, turn it on and the next time the percentage is a 1% higher

- Battery + built in wifi = bad: If you are going to download thumbnails / boxart or update cores / assets, do it while connected to the DC and disable wifi immediately after. It sucked a 30% just doing that.

- Gaming experience: Surprised to see it can do CPS3 with not a lot of hiccups. GBA paired with the LCD3X shader mitigates well enough the scaling artifacts when not using integer scaling. 240p PSX games like Klonoa are the ones that benefit the most from the small screen. Snes and Nes are as annoying as ever with the non square pixels if you have bad OCPD about stretching artifacts, as usual.

- Comfort: The d-pad is placed higher than on the og gameboy, so the corner gets into the soft of the hand and hurts a bit until you learn to adapt the posture. The analog stick placement justifies why I did not want the model with two of them. For Ridge Racer Type 4 I just place the left hand lower to not feel it too much. If I really wanted to play an analog only game, I would end using the Gamesir X2 instead.

- Commuting and travelling: Beats lugging around a Nintendo Switch for a quickie in the train. Easier to store. Loses points for not having bluetooth. I can do without wifi, but headphone cables are always a risk

- Did I really need this: Sure, it's cool to be able to play MVS Meta Slug X on the go, but then I ask myself why would I want to play on a "tiny screen" when I can do it on a 40" tv and see all the details. It's great as a replacement for aging handheld consoles, but for TV out consoles it may be better to get one of the other handhelds with bigger screens

That's it for now, I guess. Decent hardware, Need to find a pouch for it. the grey color, rather than the old GB, reminds me more of the Watara Supervisision.

>>9544585
>random knock off device
No. It’s the gp2x the successor to the gp32 the first handheld emulation machine ever made, shit for brains. Both of these consoles were huge in the home brew scene and sparked the handheld emulation scene we have today. I’m dead serious. Gamepark split up after making the gp32, which caused the gp2x to be made, but the teams were competing with each other which eventually led to the pyra and the gpd win to be the competitors. That was the beginning of the hand held computer and handheld emulation machine fad that we see now. It all stems from the massive home brew scene on the gp32 and gp2x. It doesn’t get you very far being a dumb faggot, but now you know.

What was your first experience playing Doom?
>late 1994 sunday afternoon
>7yr old me, obsessed with Mortal Kombat 2

>dad brings home a big box with cool artwork and floppies inside
>"drop your nintendo, anon, I've got something here"
>"nooo dad, not your simulators again"
>(I actually loved playing F117 with him but all I wanted to play at the moment was Mortal Kombat 2)
>"It's a shooter game like contra but it's in first person like you are watching the action with your own eyes, anon"
>"yeah dad, like in your simulators. This is a really stupid idea"
>dad switches on the PC. I don't like it much because "Super Nintendo has cooler games" and I'm always afraid to break it somehow. I am not allowed to switch it on and use it on my own
>Windows 3.1 starts but dad shuts it down to "free the memory"
>starts a blue-windowed shell instead
>I am looking at the game box while the game installs. It says Doom II
>some of my classmates were joking about Doom when the lights went flickering in the class. Never seen the game myself and never knew that there are two of them
>after the setup process the game is launched, first level starts, I see pic related
>"huh, these stairs look cool"
>dad moves around, shoots
>"definitely cool"
>I ask to try myself and for the rest of the session it's just me playing and dad watching me play and giving advice
>we finish the game a couple of weeks later. Keyboard only, frequently getting scared and lost in the levels, save scumming
>It's the best gaming experience in my life, thanks dad.

>>9560493
For $5000 you could get a brand new Pentium computer around 1993 and have about half left over (people didn't do this at the time). Doom only needed a 486 to run well, which hovered at around $1000 at the time, and would keep dropping. By the time Doom 2 was in stores, a 486 computer with a mouse and the memory to use it together with the game would be WELL under the $1000 mark. Not to talk about the older and much cheaper 386 machines which would run the game well enough in low detail mode and the screen size cut down a step or two, with the original game's first episode being widely available dirt cheap, or even for free. Most people probably experienced it this way, many using the 386 or even 486 at their school, university, or workplace.
That's in addition to said PC, even on the lower end, being capable of playing MANY other good games, as well as all kinds of office, work, and utility software.

To conclude, your dad should have pulled out, because clearly he couldn't afford to raise you if the prospect of playing Doom was prohibitively expensive. You must have grown up somewhere incredibly poor and undeveloped.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9561281
>For $5000 you could get a brand new Pentium computer around 1993
You'll need that if you want full and consistent framerate.
>Doom only needed a 486 to run well
With basic ass 486DX-33, you needed to set the quality to minimum and reduce the window size by 25% or less to get a comfortable framerate.
>which hovered at around $1000 at the time
More like $2000 for the basic ass 486DX-33. Even a shitty 386DX would be well over $1000. A bare minimum spec PC with 486DX2 66MHz, the minimum CPU for running Doom comfortably, would run you up for almost $2500. 486SX was choppy as hell and with 486DX you needed to scale down the screen size by something like 25% and set the quality down to minimum, but it will still get choppy when the game throws more enemies at you. Not sure if using more RAM than the minimum spec of 4MB will help the game run better, I suppose it does at higher quality and resolution.
>Not to talk about the older and much cheaper 386 machines which would run the game well enough in low detail mode and the screen size cut down a step or two
More like in half or less.
>That's in addition to said PC, even on the lower end, being capable of playing MANY other good games, as well as all kinds of office, work, and utility software.
Just not Doom, it was one of the most demanding games back then. You'd have much better luck playing it on atari jaguar.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9561337
>You'll need that if you want full and consistent framerate.
If you wanted the full 35fps at all times, sure, but the vast majority of people hadn't ever experienced that with a game of that graphical fidelity (compare to Ultima Underworld). The game being able to stay consistently above 20fps was already incredibly fluid for most people at the time. Compare.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=foHUXGzHOx0

Never mind that you definitely did not have to spend up to $2500. You didn't have to buy a complete pre-built, you could build your own, even reuse components from an older computer (such as the screen, keyboard, mouse, speakers), depending on what you start out with, you could even replace the 386 on the motherboard with a 486, and a weaker 486SX can be replaced with a better 486DX, the previous one can be sold off to cover expenses. You can also save a lot by skipping a CD-ROM drive, which would start at like $200 alone by 1994, Doom was available on floppies.

If you had already invested in a 386 prior, you didn't need to spend a fortune on getting decent performance with Doom, nor did you if you had a lower end 486. Some computers with 486s could also be upgraded to Pentium, which could become relevant for later games.

It was purple, had an archaic GUI, and shareware versions of tons of Doom era shooters (Wolf 3D, SOD, Doom, Blake Stone, Corridor 7, Ken's Labyrinth, etc.) along with modded versions of some of the games like Enigma's Nightmare for Wolf3d and the SImpsons mod for Doom. Half of them didn't work, I was too afraid to actually play Doom for real so I just would turn off monsters.

Disc also had Bad Toys, which was a ridiculous game, but really appealed to me as a kid.

I have a tendency to open a door, take a step in maybe take a single shot at something, then immediately run away and hide in a corner hoping the in-fighting kills each other or at least weakens some of the enemies before I return and mop up the remainder. That with the item management with backtracking, just makes for a somewhat tedious experience and is probably not interesting to others. I enjoyed doing so, but it does not appear to be the optimal way others play. I did like the original Doom, it's sequel was okay, but I'm not as high on the game as so many others here are.

That's the case with pretty much any CRT TV.
They have a fixed hz refresh rate.

VGA CRT monitors on the other hand you can change the refresh rate and thus also change the noise it makes.

For example 50 fps video at 50hz looks like shit to me on a CRT so I run the CRT at 100hz.

The PS1 supports the SNES's resolution so it matches. The Saturn is like the Genesis and doesn't go that low so they pillarboxed it rather than stretching it like the SOTN port did. But they also failed to stretch the game image to 4:3 so you're playing an 8:7 emulator-like version set inside a window. PS1 just looks normal.

>>9555159
It's possible to force your switch to use the 1.0.0 version of Atari 50 that has Warbirds still in it. The issue is, you need to do a factory reset on your switch. As long as you've let a physical game update, you can't run that game ever in the future without having at least that update. There's some sort of data that remains after you delete data that tells the switch you NEED to update before you can play. Factory reset is the only way to clear that data. Factory reset your switch, then take it offline and put the cartridge in and install the game and disable auto-updates for that game, then your switch should have Atari 50 with Warbirds and can be safely taken back online.
I know your anger, I felt it the day I brought home a PS2 and MGS3 Substance and was all excited to play Metal Gear Online, only to find out they shut the servers down a few months prior.

>>9556962
>This could effect all games on all consoles btw. What's to stop them from sending updates like this to all other collections or standalones? The future looks grim.

It's actually much worse than that. When it becomes sufficiently practical, and eventually it will, mainstream single-player games will not only be online-only but streaming-only. The general public will embrace the convenience of paying a subscription to access all the games in a provider's library, without having to worry about disk space, let alone shelf space. This all-you-can-play model will take the edge off how they don't actually *own* anything in that library, whose contents are subject to change without notice.

There will be nothing for us to back up, unpatch, crack, pirate, or preserve, because all the code and assets will be out of reach on some corporate cloud server. You will have no recourse when they change a game, retire it, or revoke your access for whatever reason.

No matter how digitally locked down they are, movies, music, and ebooks can at least be recorded through the analog hole (i.e. filming the screen), but games will be at the absolute mercy of rightsholders.

t. Cassandra

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9560002
The Lynx has a custom 16 bit 16Mhz CMOS handling the sprites and rendering the graphics, and a 4Mhz 65C02 (clocked faster than the SNES CPU) handling the general game logic. It also has a dedicated math ASIC that could transform the sprites quickly or something like that. Not even the SNES or Genesis could match the Lynx's performance, let alone the 7800. It's a low res amiga on steroids.

I dunno why people call it the videogames crash of 1983-1985 or 1984. Consoles and arcades were in a decline starting in 1980. Computer gaming was on the rise during the same period. All thanks to the new cheap micro-computers like the Apple II, Atari ST, C64, etc. Computer gaming hit a slump in 1985 until 1988-89 when VGA started getting widespread and not just cutting edge. Consoles hit a slump themselves in 1993 and didn't recover until 1996, and arcades were going down in profits during the same time. Never hear anyone talk about the computer videogames crash of 1985-1988 or the videogames crash of 1993-1996.
The only difference is there was a major recession in the early 1980's. So somehow the recession-related cutback on customer spending is a major videogames crash event, but all the other times the industry has seen their market get cut in half is business as normal. And Nintendo is somehow the savior of videogames for launching the NES at the start of an economic boom period. Never hear anyone say Sid Meier, Jordan Mechner, or Al Lowe saved computer gaming for the growth in PC gaming in 1989.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9561476
>And less than 50 were built.

1993 was pre-internet so information is not available on the exact amount. However my research confirms around 25 to 30 Ridge Racer Full Scale Units were exported for Western/Foreign markets. They were spread across the USA, UK, Spain, France, Middle East, Australia, etc.

And around 20 Ridge Racer Full Scale were used in Asian markets. Namco themselves kept several units in reserve to use in their Namco branded theme parks and Namco arcades in Japan. Several independent arcade owners in Asia had a Ridge Racer Full Scale too. A few malls had them as well. In the 1990s, any business owner could buy it from Namco if they had the money.

Trust me. Namco would NOT invest money in a factory, put Ads in sales magazines (for arcade owners), make sales flyers, and only make a small handful of Ridge Racer Full Scale Units. You need bulk sales to make it worth the investment.

Different anon here. I actually had the chance to purchase a Ridge Racer Full Scale 20 years ago. The owner was closing his arcade and offered to sell it to me. But the guy wanted $15K. At most I could maybe $8K and the owner wouldn't come down in price.

It was 10 years old and the machine kinda worn, but it still worked. The interior needed to be redone. The leather interior and everything was worn down. But I ended up passing on it. $15K was a big ask for a 10+ year old arcade machine that was used and needed refurbishment. This was like 2004. Most home consoles looked far better than Ridge Racer Full Scale in terms of graphics. The arcade market had also crashed and many arcades were shutting down. Xbox live and online play had killed arcades.

I'm wondering if I made a mistake passing on this machine considering only a small amount were made and it seems no one else in the whole world saved their Ridge Racer Full Scale machines.

>>9563351
>are you sure? i saw one of these at pontins in prestatyn in late 90s/early 00s. If they only made 50 it's hard to imagine one would have ended up some run down holiday camp jn North Wales
No one knows the exact number for sure. Literally anyone with $250,000 to blow could have ordered a Ridge Racer Full Scale from Namco between 1993 and 1998. I'm not saying only 50 units were made. All I know is that I could only confirm around 50 with my research but more could have been made. It would not surprise me if more were manufactured.

Arcade collectors on forums like to say that only around 20 ridge racer full scale units were ever made, and pretend it was some sort of super rare machine. Which is complete bullshit. Namco would not invest millions into tooling an entire arcade factory and only make 20 units. They aren't Sega. Namco is actually well known for being financially responsible. It would not surprise me if 100 or 200 were made. I've talked to people that claim they saw Ridge Racer Full Scale in malls, movie theater lobbies, big arcades, theme parks, beach resorts, airports, etc.

>imagine one would have ended up some run down holiday camp jn North Wales
Your holiday camp probably bought them used at a big discount. During the early 2000s, many arcades were closing down because the arcade market crashed and never recovered. Businesses were selling their arcade machines on eBay and several websites for super cheap. That includes Ridge Racer Full Scale. I remember seeing them for sale. You could have gotten it for cheap if you had a few thousand dollars back then. I'm guessing a few places picked up a Full Scale for cheap and got a couple more years of use out of it until the machine broke down and was scrapped. Sucks that no one saved even one working unit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9564774
Arcade business owners paid huge sums of money for arcade cabinets with the promise that they will earn their investment back in 6 months and start earning profit. Ridge Racer Full Scale was no different.

An arcade owner could pay $200,000 for Ridge Racer Full Scale. Yes that's huge for an arcade. But they could charge $5 dollars per play. Let's assume when it first came out that 500 people per day played Ridge Racer Full Scale. That $2,500 dollars a day. That's about $75,000 a month. That's $450,000 in 6 months. That's $900,000 in 1 year. It's already more than paid for itself.

I know you think these numbers are silly and absurd. But you don't understand. The 80s and 90s were a different time. Arcades were incredibly popular back then. A cultural phenomenon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9564825
Ah...these ski machines. These things used to be everywhere. There aren't many "old school" Namco or Sega ski arcade machines like Super Alpine racer around anymore in arcades.

These machines saw a lot of abuse. People were very rough on the machines and the foot mechanisms were prone to breaking without periodic maintenance. People slamming their whole body weight left and right would eventually cause something to break. Many of these machines would break down as years passed.

The rear projection screens also were an issue as time passed. The bulbs inside needed to be replaced after a certain amount of hours of use. The bulbs cost money, and arcade owners don't want to invest money in keeping the screen running. Especially when LCD technology is now available.

They are also very bulky. If you do see a ski machine in arcades, it's probably a new one made Raw Thrills.

I'm not saying these old school Namco or a Sega Ski Machines are rare to find...Or that they worth a lot of money. They are out there and You could definitely find one for sale if you want on some websites. But shipping is expensive and it will probably need some sort of maintenance done.

Many arcade owners simply got rid of them after several years rather than continue maintaining them.

If you look at the history of both companies, Namco was always #1 in terms of sales. But it was an INTENSE rivalry.

Sega was always a close #2 in arcade. Sega tried really hard to beat Namco and the rivalry was crazy. Sega came close several times, but couldn't over take Namco in arcade sales.

In fact, you can read interviews from former Sega Executives and Employees that talked about how there was intense pressure internally at the company to beat Namco.

And Namco had to fight very hard to stay #1 in arcades when Sega challeneged them. Namco even went so far as to steal Sega employees and offer them higher salaries and wages if they defected and came to Namco.

And? My point is that these ports are ok. What's yours? We settled for much less during the 16-bit generation so having A3 and D3 at home at this quality was great. Especially since Saturn versions stayed in Japan.
>The N64 with the expansion pak has 8MB of unified RAM.
Unified RAM doesn't help when texture cache is only 4kb and bottlenecks the whole system when it has to be explicitly asked to constantly fetch new data from RAM. PS1 texture cache on the other hand is an associative cache so it takes no CPU cycles to be updated and VRAM size is the only limit.
In short, N64 port of a Capcom fighting game can have arcade perfect animation stored in RAM but actually displaying it at real time would stall the whole thing.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9562198
Ok, since you guys continue to insist, let's check MK Trilogy closely.
First of all, MK games have simplistic backgrounds with many tiling and repeating elements. Compare this with CPS2 games that have more big and unique, sometimes animates objects in their backgrounds.
Next, the chatacters animations. MK Trilogy sprites are very thin and don't have much unique animations. SF Alpha games are kind of simple too but Darkstalkers and Marvel vs games have more elaborate attack animations that take a large chunk of screen (and VRAM). MK Trilogy being this lightweight on animations is pretty much confirmed by the PS1 version: it easily holds 4 unique characters for 2 on 2 combat in PS1 RAM - when one character is defeated the game doesn't stop to load the second one from the disc. No Capcom game manages to have four complete and unique characters in a single fight on PS1 because they take much more memory than Mortal Kombat ones.
N64 has more RAM and doesn't have to deal with loading from the disk at all, so it allows SIX unique characters in 3 on 3 combat. Great, right? But here's the deal: the animation quality is worse than in PS1 version. So while there are six characters in N64 RAM, even having only two of them on screen, N64 can't animate them as fast as PS1 version. This is barely a cart size issue - adding a couple of frames to each character standing idle animation would make them look a whole lot smoother and this takes a very little space of ROM. MKT ROM has a enough of padding (aka unused space) for this. Even without using the unused space they could just remove that fancy MK logo in flames title screen and shitty looking MK1 stages and add better animation instead. But they didn't because N64 can't run it as smooth anyway.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9562805
There are certainly no 1800 sprites in Mario Kart. It makes a heavy use of composed sprites, aka sprites made from separate elements. Car is animated separately, wheels are animated separately and superimposed over thr car sprite. And then finally the chracter sprite is added on top. Using dynamic palettes for car colors you may "construct" unique sprites for every racer. The sprites themselves are very nicely and smoothly animated but they are very small in size. And finally, the game doesn't run at 60 fps. It runs at 30 and it's enough to fetch needed data from VRAM to buffer. A 2D fighting game at 30 fps would be a big downgrade.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9562805
>N64 could use the cart rom chip like RAM and stream data much faster than any optical media console on the market
And just to add to this, no cart based system actually does this. It still has to use RAM or different caches in between. The question is how fast can it fetch the data? Not to mention that many N64 games had to use compressed graphics so the system had to take the data from the cart, then uncompress it to RAM and only then it could use it. It wasn't free.
The system that operates very similar to what you describe is Neo Geo. I don't remember exact details but SNK didn't bother with ROM sizes and memory costs and used the biggest ones available because they could sell the carts at a big cost anyway. And then NG architecture allowed them to stream the graphics from ROM to RAM almost for free. N64 was built with different strengths in mind (fast 3D scene calculations) and it wasn't optimized to toss large sprites around with the same ease.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
So CPS2 games use frame skipping to enable their turbo modes. The higher turbo mode the more frames are skipped.
But instead you could do this in reverse. You can run the gameplay logic at 60 fps internally while only displaying 50 fps sprite updates but stretching out the time the frame is on screen to make the gameplay speed still the "normal" speed*. This won't have much of an effect on the visual appearance of the game because sprites are often held on screen for multiple frames anyway so rarely will an important frame get skipped. It would result in some animations being longer than normal.**

There were other tricks used in the PS1 ports that should work here. Changing the hit sparks to 3d graphics is the first thing. The life bars could also be 3d. That's a little bit of memory savings. I think you could probably do something for the in-game timer to make it out of 3d graphics as well. Not numbers but maybe something like a two colored wheel that runs out.

*Tournament players would cry about the slowness but it is what it is.
**This would make occasional differences to the gameplay by having a move be one or two more frames of animation longer on screen resulting in something that would usually be safe on block to be punishable.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Also I think it is important to remember her that although the game engine of these CPS2 games run in 60 fps the graphics do not often change at that speed. The various moves the characters do have animations that last per sprite frame on screen for multiple display refreshes.

>>9563240
The information you describe is totally wrong.
Most cart consoles have memory-mapped ROM with RAM-like access timing. Sprite streaming is a common practice. Its easy to see it in Mario Kart Super Circuit, for example, by opening a VRAM viewer or tweaking the ROM timing in an emulator.
The Neo Geo outright used ROM for sprites instead of RAM, not even needing streaming. NES also usually functioned this way, though the cart could decide to use RAM instead. (CHR ROM/CHR RAM)

>>9564103

The PS1 can be characterized as "half-software" because the geometry transforms are done through a CPU coprocessor, then sent to a mostly-2D GPU capable of filling in the gaps with affine transformations. This unusual pipeline accounts for why the rendering artifacts have a system-defining character to them - information about the geometry is lost after leaving the CPU and the GPU operates at screenspace precision, making the biggest polygons onscreen the most visibly inaccurate

>>9566130
I'm not saying I don't believe you, it's just that there aren't any specific examples to point to other than the higher end N64 games from Rare and Factor 5 that do pull a lot of tricks to work around the texture cache limits. We're really stuck in a loop with some people saying "it's not fast enough" and the others saying "yes it is." The CPS2's resolution is 384x224. Let's say the N64 limits that to 320x224, which is the same as the Saturn port. A lot of N64 games run at higher resolutions than that. Perfect Dark's high res mode is 640x222. 480x360 was common, too. So while the N64 had trouble hitting higher framerates it was also punching above it's weight class in resolution. Bring that down to what the CPS2 needs and you're no longer stressing the system as much when it's time to actually draw it.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9563434
>It would result in some animations being longer than normal.**
Thinking over it again the animations would be the same length but what you would do is repeat the same sprite as before or after the sprite you frame skipped over.

So if you were doing a 1/6 frame skip you'd skip every sixth frame and replace it with either the frame in front of it or behind it. You could make this alternate if you wanted, or come up with more elaborate plans.
I *think* this should result in a significant saving of resources without making too much of a hit on the gameplay since the arcade version is typically played in "Turbo" mode that employs a frame-skip. So players are used to that and accept it. But here instead of using the frame skip to increase gameplay speed you're keeping the same speed but saving resources to free up time for the N64 hardware to keep up.
Again, this does result in the game running in what in the arcade version is the slow "normal" speed option.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
A few years ago I spent hours A/B testing my Wii against a Toaster NES. I fucking LOVE the NES so this is not a Zoomer opinion. There are two parts to the story. The TL;DR is that besides the slightly off scaling (that I wasn’t able to match) and a color palette that was a lot brighter (in a good way) I didn’t find any issues … UNTIL I SOLD MY NES.

Seems like I found all the problems once the hardware NES was gone. IN GENERAL, I don’t think you will be aware of it, however in some games (like Super C) the camera on the diagonal climbs in level one didn’t work properly. I remember finding other issues with some games (slow down, stuttering) but it wasn’t game breaking.

In short, keep your NES but use the Wii for convenience. Input lag wasn’t a huge issue on a CRT (you can use a wired controller too you casual).

SNES obviously doesn’t work perfect. Contrary to what anon said earlier in this thread, Starfox 2 doesn’t run correctly. Maybe it’s my rom but it was a bit weird when I tried it years back. Also, YOSHIS ISLAND is a meme test game, THE SNES TEST GAME IS MARIO RPG.

Mario RPG will skull fuck an emulator. And the wii SNES emulator does not run Mario RPG, HOWEVER most games are fine/perfect enough.

GBA runs like trash if you use VBAnext but MGBA seems to run every game at full speed, I never encountered any issues but I’ve only tried a couple of games. What didn’t work in VBANEXT worked in mGBA.

I played snatcher on the wii genesis emulator and I remember at some point I had to switch to another cause it was starting to lock up.

The Wii is perfect for gaming. Emulation accuracy is good enough for $50, native CRT support, massive library. Also as other anons point out the virtual console ports seem to remedy accuracy issues.

>Wii
Wii/GC
>PS3
PS1,PS2,PS3,PSP, EMULATION UP TO CPS3
>XBOX OG
XBOX OG GAMES
>PC/LAPTOP
Everything in between

^^^ This is the winning strategy.

Can I ask which emulator you used last? The latest builds for snes and nes are FCEUltraRX and Snes9xRX.

I grew up with Super C and didn’t recognize a problem with vertical scrolling when I tried it right now. Scrolling was always weird with the little white boarder on top even with real hardware. I did see definite graphical problems with the Cheetahmen intro for Action 52 and some possible gameplay bugs but that whole fucking game is a glitch so it’s hard to say if something is going wrong. I’ve heard others say Action 52 is the hardest NES game to emulate but it’s hard to agree when the game isn’t an official release.

I’ve been emulating since the Dingoo days so I know how Super Mario RPG was the holy grail of emulation for a long time. Tried it right now and found no obvious issues with stuttering or the menus. If you aren’t using Snes9xRX then you have to try Starfox 2. The nintendo logo has a tiny bit of stuttering but everything else plays great. Maybe it has some frame skip but the game overall is so choppy it’s hard to tell what’s intentional.

I’m not saying it’s perfect. On Mega Man X2 there’s a 1/4 second hiccup right before the intro miniboss fight. And in Sim Earth the intro sequence is rough. What I am saying is that I’m sure all these games can be played to completion, all the heavy hitters play great, I haven’t seen any games that just won’t load at all and that’s all a huge accomplishment.

>It’s really starting to sound like the people who are complaining about emulation on Wii haven’t tested it out in 5+ years.

Most of the major emulators still get updates and you even have different forks to choose from. Obviously no one should expect perfect accuracy* on the Wii, but you can still play a large amount of games pretty well and the compatibility with CRT TVs is a nice bonus. It's just a matter of bothering to research and grabbing the latest versions.

*An outlier is Genesis Plus GX, which started out on GameCube and actually advanced the state of Mega Drive emulation. You can even do stuff like playing Snatcher CD with the Wiimote as a light gun.

>Yes, PS1 doesn’t work well, I couldn’t even get SOTN to run correctly and that’s the base game I try with any PS1 emulator.
I think that worked alright with dithering turned off, the only major issue was CDDA not working and that has been fixed this year with WiiStation and WiiSXRX, along with many others things. Haven't tried these builds myself, but I was able to play a large chunk of Chrono Cross a couple of years ago surprisingly well.

>N64 is shit as well unless you really like the Chameleon Twist series.
Eh, you can play much more than that. Like yeah, Wii64/Not64 isn't perfect, but it is one of the most advanced Wii homebrew projects period. I was even able to beat Rayman 2 on that thing.

>OP also claimed 32X doesn’t work right but now I’m starting to wonder about that too.

Managed to play After Burner Complete and Knuckles' Chaotix at full FPS with Picodrive, dunno about the 3D stuff but I saw Virtua Racing Deluxe on a YouTube video running well.

another thing that gets looked over too easily when discussing compatibility is light gun support. Something that very few emulation tv boxes do and not something you’re likely to enjoy on PC. I realized just recently that I've been playing with my geometry settings completely wrong for almost two years. - CRTs are no longer produced because they have inferior picture quality versus LCDs
- CRTs emit dangerous levels of X-rays or other forms of radiation
- CRTs always have easily-visible flicker
- CRTs always cause eyestrain
- CRTs always make a high-pitched squealing noise
- CRTs contain lethal amounts of electricity, even when unplugged
- CRTs need calibration more than two to three times a year
- Overall CRT black levels are not superior to LCDs because ambient light ruins CRT black levels
- Analog CRTs have more processing time than digital LCDs due to poor RAMDAC performance
- Afterimages caused by phosphor decay are extremely annoying and are a significant downside of CRTs
- Sending an improper mode (resolution or refresh rate) to a CRT can cause permanent damage
- CRTs cannot have touchscreens
- 4:3 is so bad that nobody should use a non-widescreen CRT
- The Sony GDM-FW900 is the only CRT worth owning
- Curved CRTs have objectively inferior picture quality versus flat CRTs with otherwise equal specifications
- CRTs should not be used because they are heavier and deeper than LCDs
- CRTs have severe reflections because they do not have matte coats
- CRTs can be permanently damaged by nearby magnets
- You will not have sex in 2023
- Analog signals limit a CRT's resolutions and refresh rates and negatively effect picture quality
- Heavy metals are used in CRT glass to reduce radiation

>>9556104
> Analog CRTs have more processing time than digital LCDs due to poor RAMDAC performance
perhaps true for graphics cards and monitors, but that is the fault of the graphics card, not the CRT.
an NTSC signal directly drives the electron beam. it don't get no faster than that. video game consoles used a technique called "double strike" to get 240p instead of 480i, essentially sending an invalid NTSC signal to get the beam to draw the same lines instead of alternating. hence those scanny ass scanlines.
> CRTs cannot have touchscreens
they sure as fuck did, and they existed since the early 80s. they were common on ATM machines.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ExKowj2g8N8
> CRTs contain lethal amounts of electricity, even when unplugged
fuck yeah they do =)
seriously be careful if you decide to fuck around inside of one.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9550859
It's functionally identical to an F-type connector that you typically associate with RF input. It's the same signal just shaped differently.

Any RF box will do. Or actually, you don't even need a box; the purpose of that box was so that you could hook up your console without having to give up access to your TV channels. But since analogue TV isn't a thing anymore, it's a moot point. For instance you can just hook a Nintendo or Atari straight into the coax port without a box and it'll work just fine (actually better since less chance of interference from a shitty box)

If you have an s-video port then you don't need a s-video to scart adapter. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9558619
completely normal, especially for the top and bottom. its called overscan. you'll notice most old games don't have status bar information in the very top and bottom of the screen because of this reason.
a little bit is fine and normal: about 8 pixels or one square in any direction. just center it the best you can.
FCEUX by default cuts off the top and bottom 8 pixels of the screen by default, it was assumed TVs just were this way.
WARNING: you don't want to go crazy adjusting it either: if you make it perfect for your NES, your SNES and PlayStation will be out of whack, etc etc. analog signals were never perfect.

>>9563724
you might live in an area where there just aren't many crts, but here are some more options:
-check your listings daily for several months, including curb alerts, garage/yard sales (if such things exist where you live), and estate sales
-create a wanted/buying listing on craigslist
-expand your search area and do a road trip
-ask your friends and relatives if they have any laying around
-see if you can't get any from a local recycling facility, including any organizations that accept electronic donations for reuse
-thrift stores, although some don't accept crts anymore
-flea markets and swap meets
if all that fails or if it's easier, you could pay ebay price and hope the seller packages it properly

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9565176
>So PVM is just an even better Trinitron?
"Trinitron" is a brand of CRT. "PVM" is a line of Sony monitors, some of which contain Trinitron CRTs, with others using flat panel LCDs or OLEDs.
>They're pretty small though
Sony made PVMs ranging from 8 inches all the up to 42 inches. They also have a line of BVMs which go up to 32 inches.
>I guess the trade-off is you have to choose between great image and larger screen, or even better image and smaller screen?
Other way around actually. Larger PVMs typically have better image quality, though, image quality has little to do with screen size. Resolution/dot pitch is what matters. Typically, though, the smaller the screen the lower the resolution.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9565779
Use something you can run 240p test suite on or maybe a dvd with test patterns on it.
Is the picture dim at max brightness? Does it have color purity issues?
Is the geometry good? Do lines look like lines and circles look like circles? Does the image look tilted?
How is the convergence? It's typical to have problems but is it noticeable if you're not looking at a test pattern?
Some of this stuff is fixable if you know what you're doing, but I'd avoid anything with big geometry problems or a dim picture.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Atari were always most comfortable in the arcade style and could never really adjust when games started to get deeper.

An element of that is the fact that they never seemed to understand how integral decent music and sound are to the home gaming experience so they always treated it as an afterthought. The 7800 used the same sound chip as the 2600. The Lynx was touted as having a 32-bit sound processor, but in practice seemed like only a minor sonic upgrade from the 2600/7800. Even on the Jag, stuff like the soundtrack in Tempest 2000 was the exception. Many Jag games didn't even bother with music at all.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9561389
>The Lynx was touted as having a 32-bit sound processor, but in practice seemed like only a minor sonic upgrade from the 2600/7800
It had an 8 bit 4-channel DAC which could be switched into PSG mode. It could sound nearly as nice as the SNES sound chip provided you gave it good samples. Most Lynx games use the PSG sound mode, perhaps to save some ROM. But in DAC mode, it sounds great.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2NJOJ9roJ9E
>Many Jag games didn't even bother with music at all.
Most Jag games were distributed in 2MB carts. Most developers were too lazy or too poor to hire good musicians to compose great sounding sampled music for them. Tempest 2000 was an exception.

Its got tons of games, so let me recommend you the games the NES couldn't possibly replicate instead. There's not even a NES equivalent for Star Raiders, atari's 1979 killer app on an 8 bit cart. posts.name: Anonymous

>>9566841
>atari 8-bit is atari's 8-bit line of home computers
It was built for gaming. It had sprite system, projectile system, 4 channel sound chip, cart slot, and some BASIC clone that sucked because Atari cheaped out on that.
>it was the only powerful 8-bit home computer until commodore 64 came along. both C64 (commodore 64) and atari 8-bit is the only powerful 8-bit computers of the 80s
Now that's stupid. Yes the Atari 8-bit and C64 had a powerful sprite system, but others had their own strengths. The BBC Micro was a 6502 computer clocked at a whopping 2MHz, Elite ran smooth as a butter on it. ZX Spectrum could update its screen faster than any bitmap graphic home computer of its days. The CPC was, I think, the only 8 bit computer with no colour attribute limitations, and it was pretty fast too considering what it was. The PC-88 had a really high screen resolution.
But yes, for gaming purposes, nothing beat the Atari 8-bit and C64.
>if you mean atari st's processing speed then yes, it is far powerful than amiga
Of course, blast processing beats the 'migger.

>>9560230
this p much. zero mission doesn't replace or "improve" metroid 1 because they're drastically different in feel and presentation. they're both good and people saying there's no reason to play m1 when zero mission exists are fucking stupid
it's the same with m2 vs AM2R. they're just too different to say no one should ever play m2 again when _ exists.

by modern standards m2 does suck; too many identical tilesets and the metroid fights are missile spam shit. by 90s standards it was pretty dope. missile spam WAS metroid boss fights (and continued to be), there's a linear path forward so you don't get lost, but each area can be explored freely. other than the lack of color, it's a huge improvement over m1 with more detailed sprites and better controls. lack of a map doesn't matter as much as in m1.

AM2R "zero missions" the game as much as it can, with the modern powerups being forced in, weird gimmick mechanics in rooms, new rooms grafted into previously empty corners. metroid fights are better but still kinda shit, the AM2R bosses are kinda shit as well but they don't feel too out of place aside from the fucking super jetpack robot torizo.
overall it's really impressive for a fan project and i'd say worthy of being an official game if it had more nintendo polish on the gfx and sfx.

samus returns fucking sucked and i despise MercurySteam for the wretched experience and getting their hands on metroid 5. i so badly wish nintendo curated and protected the metroid franchise as carefully as they do with mario and zelda, but instead metroid gets passed around to every 3rd party studio that's interested, no matter how little they understand what made metroid enjoyable. yeah i mad

Do you dedicate completion only for a few selected titles or do you go for it more often than not? I feel that it'd be interesting to see everyone's approaches to this sort of thing, as it's something that kept getting more and more common with each passing console generation, and nowadays it's everywhere, with things like trophies and achievements being quite common to see.

Have you ever deliberately gone for a 100% run before?
What 100% completion are you the most happy with getting?
What was the most difficult 100% you've ever gotten?
Did you ever give up because you couldn't pull it off?

When it comes to this last question, there's another thing that's on my mind... did you ever get 99% completion in something, as in there's only a single thing missing for it to be 100% completed, but you couldn't do that last thing? Wheter it's an item you couldn't find, or a mission you couldn't beat, or a bug within the code that never got properly fixed, etc. If you've ever faced this situation before, either a single time or more, what was your approach? Did you try to force it as much as possible even if it stopped being enjoyable or did you move on from it in a positive way? I usually manage to pull it off, but I won't lie that there have been a few cases in which I couldn't manage it at all.

Completionism is fundamentally a simple bait from the developer to artificially and unsubstantially increase your playtime without having to add any realistic content or material whatsoever.

Yes, I personally play most games exclusively for the story, unless they are fighting games or shmups, etc. However, when I play games where it happens to seem that developers placed expectations in their audience to complete achievements or gather collectables of some sort, it quickly come across as rather insulting to me. As an belittling act towards their customers and end consumers with an low effort, easy and silencing practice to keep those busy that want to be kept so. Therefore I happen to associate completionism with superficiality, credulity and mental weakness in others.

No, I did never ever do a 100% run of any kind in any game, because that is simply not worth my time.

>>9563697
I try to give every game a fair chance, to engage with them in their own terms.

For instance, I played metroid on the nes for a few hours. I drew a map, I farmed health before bosses, I got lost. That's a feeling worth feeling, but I had enough, so I moved on.

Games aren't divine artifacts that need to be respected by fully completing them, they are the result of a few (sometimes) talented dudes making stuff up until it's fun to play and then padding it up until it has enough "content" to be sold (particularly obvious in early id games like commander keen and wolfenstein, for example, but also in the aforementioned metroid). It's OK play it while you're getting something out of the experience and drop it when you're no longer having fun. I also don't care about story in videogames, so that's never an incentive to keep playing.

>>9565940
Focus mosty on the Monk. Good stat growth per level, amazing skills (Chakra and Revive especially, group healing and reviving without needing to use MP or items) and hits hard as fuck even without being able to equip weapons. But also make sure to get a few Ninja levels (or change the character's class to Ninja and send them on errands to gain skill points without gaining any class experience and forcing the character to level up), the goal is to amass 900sp to spend on the dual-wielding ability, Two Swords. Then go back to the Monk or whatever other class. The skill name would make you think it affects swords only, but it makes you able to dual-wield any weapon on any character. For the Monk class, it makes you hit twice. You'll be an unstopable juggernaut. So yeah OP, Monk. But if you like another class, go for it, just get that Ninja skill either way - trust me, you'll want it. Oh and Ramza is honestly a jack of all trades, you can make him into anything and he'll still kick ass. I had a very fun playthrough with Geomancer Ramza as an example.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9566274
For magic users, yes. But you don't wanna level up as the Calculator, you want all of his skills, then use his skillset as the secondary one maining Black Mage or Time Mage or whatever. Terrible stat growth if you level up as the Calculator. And the way to use him is kinda like super lite programming - if condition X is met, use skill Y on everyone meeting said criteria, otherwise Z. So you can use Level (elevation) as an example - you start the map, everyone (both your team and the enemy) starts mostly on elevation level 5 (the large number on the right hand side of the screen whenever you highlight a tile) let's say, move all of your dudes one level down or up as soon as possible, when it's your magic user's turn - "use fire magic on all enemies on tiles 5 levels high", boom, you can clear an entire map like that in a few turns.

>>9566678
Tekken in the arcades was much cheaper than its competition. The first game was basically a PS1 advertisement before the console itself even came out due to running on the same hardware, and it was like a tenth of the price of a Virtua Fighter 2 cabinet.
This meant a lot more installs for those cabinets, especially outside of dedicated arcade halls.
As for the home ports the PS1 was just insanely popular and Tekken, especially 2 and 3, were some of the better 3D fighting games for it.
KI Gold was one of the more expensive home console games sold at the time at 80 bucks, Tekken games were closer to 50 and dipped all the way to 20 with Greatest Hits releases.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9566798
N64 games having high prices didn't necessarily translate to high profit
KI Gold was published by Nintendo so it's hard to say how much Rare ended up making per cart.
However for third parties would end up paying like 20 bucks per cart for even small ROMs, and KI Gold was one of the bigger early N64 games so it's probably closer to half that price being simply manufacturing costs.
Compare this to PS1 where a single disc would cost a couple bucks including royalties to Sony complete in shrinkwrap. So despite being half to a quarter of the retail price the per unit profit of Tekken was significantly higher.

Same as Street Fighter - easy to learn, hard to master. Button mashers playing at low levels still have fun but there is also a big ceiling for high level play. posts.name: Anonymous

>>9557454
Legacy of Darkness with Reinhardt is legit one of my fav N64 games. KCE Kobe really laid down the ideal blueprint for 3D Castlevania despite its troubled development, the PS2 games got rid of everything that made their work ambitious and interesting.

>>9560076
>The problem is that it came out a couple months after OoT which shits all over it as an action/platformer with lite RPG elements.

It came out exactly two months after OoT and still runs way better than it. LoD in low res mode in particular is one smooth motherfucker.

Castlevania 64 is unique, even with all the "Zelda 64 inspirations". KCE Kobe did experiment with it a lot, which is exactly why it wasn't "intuitive" to play. It simply wasn't like other games from the genre at the time, so a lot of people trashed it just because it was unique. Heck, the character movement and animation in CV64 is actually ahead of most games from the era. And the level design is for the most part fantastic, matching each locale architecturally.

Plus the superb soundtrack and sound design, of course.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9562614
It's a lot more realistic than Resident Evil games. Inventory is counted in weight and not slot, you can drop items anywhere and pick them up again, items can be thrown to damage enemies, most of the weapons are melee weapons and the guns only have about 30 bullets to be found in the entire game, shotgun shells get wet when exposed to water, and melee combat has 4 different moves that determine reach, speed, and blocking. Most of the puzzles are investigative rather than puzzle-y, half of the enemies can only be beaten by solving puzzles, and if you don't enjoy reading you will miss a huge chunk of the game's enjoyment.

One last thing that makes this game different from RE is it isn't scared or ashamed of fail states. This game is a chaotic hell and wrong steps will kill you with no way to stop your death. You can lose key items and not be able to progress. You can save and load anywhere, and you should be glad of that because the difficulty would be insane without it. It's a pretty hardcore game that will intimidate the mainstream Japanese console survival horror players. The only reason RE didn't straight up copy this game is the designers had to water down the difficulty.

>What's the best way to play it today?
Just get a gog copy. Or set it up by yourself in dosbox, don't clock the CPU too high or you won't be able to sprint.
>With smoothest controls?
Don't mind the controls, they're really simple, but it's going to be a rocky ride ahead. You'll get used to it eventually.

>>9562678
>The only reason RE didn't straight up copy this game is the designers had to water down the difficulty.

They didn't copy it because the game is full of awful design. Not that I blame the dev, they had an incredibly small team and the game is extremely impressive for its time. Its for sure worth a playthrough. But the game itself is clunky and frustrating, the camera angles are incredibly confusing and sometimes orientation and depth is hard to perceive.

Resident Evil built on its concepts, yea they neutered some cool stuff like the melee combat. Alone in the Dark also has puzzles that blow RE out of water.

But RE lasts to this day because it is a refined experience. It has less concepts, because the game is more focused on doing what it does well, rather than overloading the game with all sorts of mechanics that scarcely have a use. It is the rough diamond of the survival horror legacy.

>>9562753
>But the game itself is clunky and frustrating, the camera angles are incredibly confusing and sometimes orientation and depth is hard to perceive.
I love the camera perspective for those very reasons. It's disorienting, claustrophobic, and lets the enemies creep silently into you from the most unexpected angle. It's a proper horror game, and not a blatant speedrun bait like Resident Evil.
>Resident Evil built on its concepts, yea they neutered some cool stuff like the melee combat. Alone in the Dark also has puzzles that blow RE out of water.
RE devs don't understand the importance of silent enemies either. I'm going to say this again, enemies not making any sound while they shamble towards you is one of the best things about AitD. RE zombies make obnoxious sounds imo, it's making the enemy encounters less shocking and unnerving. I also hate the overabundance of guns and ammunition, and the fact that enemies could be easily avoided by running past them.
>But RE lasts to this day because it is a refined experience.
It has a mainstream appeal for sure. I for one find AitD 2 more enjoyable than any RE game, regardless if it's a bad sequel. AitD games encourage more experimentation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9563026
>When searching about it I find a lot of claims that it's the first survival horror game (as not, not just the first 3D one) which is simply untrue.
It's the most influential one, but far from the first. Normalfags tend to attribute the most influential games in the genres to be the first ones, like Wolfenstein 3d.
>Sweet Home was a survival horror game and that released in 1989.
There are many older ones, and it's not real time action like most survival games are. It's often cited as the first survival horror because it inspired RE, but this older PC88/PC Engine game resembles the Resident Evil series far more than Sweet Home does: https://retroconsoles.fandom.com/wiki/Shiryou_Sensen:_War_of_the_Dead

I would consider Maxwell Manor (1984) as the first true survival horror game, and Project Firestart (1989) to be the first modern conventional survival horror with elements that are found in almost every modern survival horror game.

Regarding AITD4. Virtually all versions of it (PS1, PS2, Dreamcast) have annoyingly long load times between camera angles.
Go for a GOG version on PC, it's backgrounds are very high quality, loading is instantaneous and it has fully remappable gamepad support.

If for whatever reason you absolutely need to go with a console, go with a ps1 version.

It's a very competent RE clone with some differences - puzzles are harder, text files are long as shit and they kill pacing of the game a little bit, two scenarios differ a lot compared to RE standards (one is more combat heavy, the other more puzzle-heavy), and the sole major flaw are enemies respawning. Atmosphere is gorgeous.

/v/ and /vr/ both tend to ignore this game for some reason

the feel and atmosphere of Alone in the Dark is that of a great Call of Cthulhu detective/survival horror game. the fact that you're not well equipped to fight these horrors, you must read entries, run at times, and be aware of how outmatched you are, makes this a special game. it really feels like a horror game when you start to realize you can brute force your way through everything coming for you. running from room to room to avoid a creature is very much a horror theme thats missing in games. I think a lot of players are upset because your characters are not very strong and they miss the point of the game. the horror in it is not because of big monsters and zombies, but because the unspeakable creatures and mystery that surrounds you. I played it at around your age as well its still a unique game that is overlooked because 'muh resident evil'

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9562725
Only if they're dirt cheap and not signaled in any manner what so ever.
Harsh deaths are fine, surprises don't have to be bad, but you shouldn't need clairvoyance to be able to react to or avoid it, if the ONLY possible way to come out alive from an ambush or trap is to just know that it's coming because you already fell for it and tried again, I would agree and say that's an example of bad design.

An attentive player should be able to size up the situation and the details, and assess that there could be some risk (doesn't need to be immediately obvious), or it should be realistically possible for a player comfortable with the controls and movement in the game to react to the event without knowing it's coming.
I want the feeling of "Ah, the game got me, I obviously should have been more careful or reacted differently." not "The game fucked me because the designer was unimaginative when this part was made."

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9563751
IP owners inevitably become out of touch over time.
To get into high positions in established companies of any kind, it is usually the case that you need to have a long and successful career in the business market. The higher ups are then either older men who worked themselves up over time or rich middle aged men who simply bought the company. It so happens that the older a company brand becomes the more out of touch with the consumer demand they become. The, for this problem specifically hired, market analyzing team only amplifies the whole process, as they have in most cases only raw numbers and data to go after. By chasing and misinterpreting raw data, they further distance themselves to the actual realistic customer demand that they had initially fulfilled. That is usually the case for any product oriented company with a fairly successful early stage growth rate.

My personal approach is to determine in a franchise, when and where the cracking points for passion and quality starts to substantially influence and negatively impact the end products. Then I simply ignore their mere existence in relation to the whole franchise.

>>9561779
>That's it? You just want the special move to take time to perform? An experienced player will do it as fast as just pressing b, in the end whoever practiced inputs the most will have the advantage instead of whoever uses their specials more wisely.
You're not going to see the point because you're not used to playing fighting games with another person who is able to apply enough pressure that the speed of the Shoryuken coming out actually matters. Using it as an anti-air is one thing, but doing it during the gap in a sequence of attacks, to avoid being pressured as you're getting up from the ground or as a way to knock them down immediately when they try to approach are the type of strategies special motions are meant to both limit and give more meaning to: those are all things that can be hard even for experienced players to perform when the outcome of a round hinges on it, given that fighting games tend to be very fast, and mapping the attack to a single button press, even with caveats (such as reducing i-frames) would reduce some of the complexity to the decision of doing so. More importantly, it's a way of making the game easier that also makes it more boring, and doesn't really help novice players have fun either, as it gives them less stuff to improve in and ignores the fact that they already have the option of playing in an environment where fucking up basic inputs doesn't matter nearly as much, i.e. against other beginners.
>>9561803
>So why not cut the grind? I don't care about the execution I care about the strategy
You're playing the wrong genre, then! Fighting games, much like their namesake implies, are all about emulating the exhilaration of going mano a mano with someone else, and the difficulty of executing under pressure & pulling off shit you trained for are one part of what makes the combat and strategy in them have meaning. You could always play stuff like Samsho or pick easier characters too

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9561959
Why? Even in platformers there are "basic moves" with somewhat complicated inputs. The triple jump in 3D Mario games is kinda hard to do at first, it requires some pretty precise timing. It's balanced around that, it's a move that lets you go very high and far so it's a little tricky to do in order to reward players who master the timing.

Then there are perfect guard mechanics seen in fighting games but also other genres like Mario RPGs and action games like Devil May Cry or Dark Souls, where you have to press the block button within around a tenth of a second of an attack hitting to parry and counter. Or delay combos in DMC where you need to leave gaps of a precise length of time between each press of the attack button to get the right combo to come out.

Lots of games gate certain moves behind execution requirements.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The Master System port of R-Type was the first videogame I owned. Here in my small town in Scotland, I'd say the kids I knew were divided roughly 50/50 between owning a Master System or a NES. I played Zelda 1 and SMB 2 at a friend's house, and while I did enjoy them, they didn't fill me with envy or make me regret my Master System. I did have a Game Boy, however, and when the 16-bit consoles came around I opted for a SNES, perhaps because I always, even at a very early age, had a powerful instinctive aversion to Sonic and his gay little universe.

>>9566252
The Mega Drive was the best thing Sega ever did, and is still one of the best consoles ever made.
The Saturn was certainly handled incredibly poorly, with circumstances being rough even before it would launch, but I prefer looking at the silver linings.

>>9566110
The British economy was a little tight around then, so an increasingly inexpensive machine with super easy piracy had a lasting appeal. Many of the games are pretty dull or even shitty, but there's some pretty decent ones which are easy enough to find because they got pirated the most, even if the scene had a lot of shovelware (what popular system didn't though).
Famiclones and even bootleg Master Systems were a thing you'd see here and there in Britain in those days, so options did get better even on the cheap end, and even if the ZX Spectrum was a bit weak, the Commodore 64 was just as easy to pirate for but had much better games (the best stuff was NES and MS tier), so it was really popular, and probably the best value for your money in that market.

i think it's fine, i mean the way scenario progression for the rct2 scenarios works is already quite different to how vanilla rct2 did it and infact is the cause of the weird difficulty curve of rct2
in vanilla rct2 you could just pick any scenario and there was no unlocking at all, and the expansion scenarios + any custom scenarios you had were all lumped together into a massive mess
and openrct2 already changed this years ago by implementing a more rct1 style approach where they're sorted by source games with an unlocking system. so what you're probably thinking is "vanilla" really is just how openrct2 handled it before.
plus if you really want a more rct2 accurate "progression" system then you can just disable scenario unlocking or just switch to difficulty based scenario sorting which is more like vanilla rct2 but without all of the messy organization

I remember downloading random ROMs for the VBA when I was in high school and finding The Minish Cap one weekend when I had no homework.
I played for half an hour late in the evening that saturday to see how it was and got up early the next day to play it. I kept going and going but it felt that maybe one or two hours had passed; instead, it had been eleven.
The room was dark, I had dismissed my mom when she told me breakfast and lunch were ready, and she didn't mind because she was too tired from working at the office that week and slept most of that time.
I don't remember a single thing from that game, other than fighting the final boss on monday and grinding after school the rest of that week for conchs for the little collectable figurines. I should play it again some time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Love:
>party characters except Quina and Amarant
>most locations
>music
>equipment system encourages you to hang onto old gear instead of immediately selling it once something stronger comes along
>ability system that allows you to completely re-configure your party before a boss with no penalty
>optional challenges built-in, like taking on a dragon during your first trip through the Ice Grotto, or beating that book boss in Alexandria during the first time you can encounter it
>at least 25% of the cutscenes in the game are completely optional to even look at, so you can skip them on re-plays
>wild ride of adventure up until 4th disk
>classic fantasy adventure story in videogame form
Hate:
>forced red-light-green-light minigame segment
>optional Hot and Cold minigame is required if you want to get the best gear and fight every optional boss and upgrade your chocobo
>battle loading takes 10-15 seconds
>occasionally get stuck with crap gear until you finally grind enough points to get the ability permanently and can finally switch to something better
>bullshit card game you get forced to play that sucks ass and is basically the computer abusing RNG against you
>Quina and Amarant are shallow as fuck characters that might as well not exist except the devs felt they needed a Blue Mage class and a Monk class character to balance out the available team members
>wild ride of adventure turns into boss-rush and LOLSORANDUM final area topped off with surprise real final boss no one gave a shit about in the 4th disk
Still in my top 3 FF games.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9564496

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I love load times

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9564502
FF5 in #1, and FF6 in #2. FF5 wins by a mile due to the job system. Even FF9's ability system seems horribly restrictive compared to the freedom offered with the FF5 job system. FF6 edges out FF9 since it doesn't suffer from loading times or forced mini-games, and it doesn't fall off a cliff in the last 25%. The character system is a bit limited, and you end up having to keep an eye on your experience so you don't level up with a crap Magicite if you want to really buff up your team, but the music, locations, and the ride you go through from beginning to end are all quality. Even if Kefka's Tower suffers from the same LOLSORANDUM design as Memoria, punching your way through three routes with three different teams is far more enjoyable than taking a single team through the only route. The only time FF9 gives you a reason to use anyone other than your top characters is the bossrush where you split into 4 teams of 2.

I have never understood why impatient people play JRPGs. Every one of these people whine about muh random encounters. I mean why are you playing a 40-hour(or more) game?
To me the whole fun of a JRPG is fighting enemies and managing items, MP, HP, etc, finding a great balance and getting to the end of an area barely holding on before kicking the boss's ass with a few healing items left and mage characters almost out of MP. It's tense and a struggle for survival. Then you get little nasty surprises that force you to suddenly adapt, like if you had overleveled your party in FF8 and you fight the Ruby Dragon with Laguna and co. without knowing about the dragon's SURPRISE!!! high-level party piece troll of a dick move.

>>9562387
>What makes this game so great?
No quest markers or fast travel (outside of catching rides between trade posts).
Not ruined by difficulty scaling like the rest of the series.
Actual good lore (and even better secret lore (and even better secret secret lore)).
Unique world building and aesthetics.
Wacky and exploitable gamesystems like spellcrafting that rewards creativity.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9562387
I guess I'll try and explain the appeal of the game for me:
>true adventure, you are left to your own devices, no hand holding
>custom magic spells are really fun to experiment with
>its a rags to riches type of game, you start as a noob and gradually become more powerful
>you grow an intimate understanding of the land throughout the game as you are forced to learn landmarks, factions, travel methods, backstory, etc.
>the fast travel systems are all in universe, use silt striders, boats, mages guilds to travel between cities, use your own spells to create a custom waypoint
>there is actual unique loot to find in the world, its not level scaled random loot like the other elder scrolls
>main story is VERY interesting and compelling
>just the feel of completing even a simple quest is adventurous because you are navigating based on the journals directions and your knowledge of the land

It's true that you don't get much influence in how quests play out, since most of them are task oriented.
However, variance in your playthrough will depend on WHICH factions and characters you decide to do quests for.
Factions have base stat requirements and some are mutually exclusive with others (not all though).
On top of that the music, aesthetic, and worldbuilding are all A+ so it's just enjoyable to be in Vvardenfell.

My advice is to take it super slow, don't expect it to be a masterpiece in the first hour. Your character will be a low level piece of shit that can barely hit a target or run faster than a slug.
Remember you can hold attack to charge hits and don't fight with low stamina because it affects your hit chance.
If you give the game a chance you will fall in love with the world because of how intimately you are made to learn and interact with it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Neat world with lots of places to find, lots to see and dig around in. Horrible combat and a plotline you need to put effort into giving a shit about. There's a billion items to find, but most of them don't really matter. You are given pretty much complete freedom to do whatever you want. Balance is kinda fucked, spells and skills range from worthless to entirely broken. Still pretty cool being able to fly around the world or run at Sanic speeds. Even at it's most patched and fixed, it's still buggy, glitchy, and very unstable. OpenMW doesn't exist because it's hard to run on modern OS'es, it exists to try and create a version of Morrowind that's actually stable and bug-free without trying to reverse engineer and fix every problem. The game came with the tool the devs themselves used to setup the game world and many features, allowing you to mod the game extensively. The game also supports these modifications natively as plug-ins, allowing you to turn them on and off from the main menu.
It's a mixed bag as a whole, but it has a lot going for it. It was also the first open-world fully-3D RPG on a console that I can think of. Computers had that years before Morrowind was released, but I can't think of any console RPGs that were fully-3D prior to the 6th generation, and open-world as well.

>>9562387
Just started playing it again via OpenMW. It's such an awesome little engine. No more load times or crashes. Can put hundreds of mods on with no issues if you get into modding.

Decent enough main quest. Detail rich world, A mechanic/skill system that is decently balanced and more like what true rpg gaming is about. (Wizards don't swing swords, and sword swingers don't cast magic) etc. You can do what your skill allows. So if you're shit with a bow; you'll miss A LOT until you purchase training in that skill. Very fun, in depth spellmaking system. Kino armor sets. A shit ton of hours of gameplay. The goty edition is really worth it for the dlc. etc. etc. It's a nerd game for nerds. Like, someone who plays dnd, in theory, should appreciate morrowind way more than skyrim.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Is it autistic to use filters with a CRT computer monitor? I was looking for something to make it look like a consumer CRT since games just look a little too sharp on my current setup. Not really a fan of seeing sharp pixels.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9566349
You have a couple of options. You can use a preset such as tvout+interlacing, which, combined with a superwide 480p resolution such as 3840x480, should give you something that looks like 240p, and you can then add horizontal blur on top of that to give it a softer look. Pic related was taken using just such a setup. However, be aware that you'll likely have massive scanline gaps, which most older consumer CRTs didn't have, at least not this pronounced.

You can also try running your monitor at 1280x960 and dicking around with the various CRT shaders, but they're not exactly made with CRT monitors in mind since they're made to work with LCD subpixels to draw the simulated phosphor mask, whereas your CRT already has a mask of its own, so results may not be ideal unless you turn off phosphor mask emulation entirely.

>>9562098
BF1942 was big fun when it was released and there was a wide range of skill levels present on every server. It turned into a janky mess once most people moved on to Battlefield 2 or Battlefield Vietnam. All the players left behind figured out the most efficient way to play was to either bomb people from so far up they can't be hit by AA fire, to nail people with tank fire like an artillery cannon, or to dump grenades near them. Since then, every map with planes will be the players who reached the aircraft first dominating everyone on the ground, all maps with tanks are determined by which side has more tank spawns, and maps without vehicles or jeep-only are grenade and explosive pack battles. If you find that fun, the game is still playable, otherwise it's been dead for a really long time.
I played the shit out of the game when it first came out, and I've played it a bit off and on the last couple of years. I get more enjoyment out of playing singleplayer with the bots than I do playing online with the sweaty try-hards all using the same maximum efficiency play-style that are the only people left playing anymore. If I can't have fun and get involved in crazy battles and jeep races, then I might as well just play against the AI. The AI is far from a great experience, and certainly nowhere near as dynamic as the servers used to be, but at least it doesn't insta-kill you from outside of your visible range. Certainly have never had the AI spawn-kill half the allied team on Omaha Beach with the cannons and then sink the ship almost immediately after the round started.

Mostly challenging "footsies". My favorite thing in Castlevania tends to be nailing those high commitment whips and jumps against relatively dynamic and unpredictable baddies.

Second most important being just good platforming making use of those tense high commitment jumps.

Castlevania 4 is generally just a bit too easy. Feels like the stages weren't really designed around the 8 way whipping and changeable jump arcs, since there's so many times where you can easily whip enemies from the floor below or before they can even attack you, and the platforming rarely puts too much pressure on you.

Hell I remember picking it up for the first time in ten years (with almost no memory of any of the stage layouts and bosses) and making it up to the final boss rush without a game over. That's kind of how pushover the game is. Combine that with how loooooooong it is and it can start to feel kind of monotonous in a single sitting playthrough despite how nice the art and music is.

I don't hate it but I like it mostly for the atmosphere and nostalgia. I think I'd put it below 1, 3 ,Bloodlines, x68, and Rondo in terms of level design and mechanics.

>>9553141
>You said Hagane

I've 1cc'd a lot of shmups and old games over time. I only really recorded or uploaded the ones I considered particularly challenging. Hagane I thought was an easier clear and took me very little time to do, so I didn't bother recording it.

I don't know why you think that one is a crown jewel of difficulty, I've never heard anyone hold that up on retro forums as particularly challenging. I guess the second loop where everything has super extra HP is harder

>No it's not and 99% of people agree, which is why games evolved the way they did

Even if it were true that consensus means better, that's really not true. There are tons of enduring franchises (including modern, still running ones) that are built around strategic limitations.

Dark Souls for example is pretty much just OG Classicvania combat in 3d. You have non-cancellable attack animations that are not instant and can't be moved during, mobility options which are very limited and set your trajectory in stone for a very specific location, etc.

Or then there's the enduring popularity of many horror games and action-horror games built around strategically limited controls. Resident Evil 2 Remake may have done away with tank controls, but it still put harsh limitations on players movement and dodging options and it was applauded for it. The same could be said of Dead Space 1 and 2 which are absurdly popular and are more or less based on the same very rigid control limitations of RE4-5 and Remake 2, just applied to a more high adrenaline action game.

Making it so you can move and attack at the same time or change the trajectory of mobility moves isn't better or worse (or even more popular are less). It's a design decision that enforces different styles of play.

posts.name: Anonymous
