>>9553073
>cant kill Shaft
Grab the Bible from the breakable wall before the boss rush, it makes every boss easier but especially Shaft because you can use it to knock away his fireballs. For the lightning orbs, admittedly that's kind of a crapshoot but if they start drifting away from each other you want to be between them, towards each other you need to backflip away from both of them ASAP. For his third attack, try to backflip over the orbs when they come towards you. It's tough but doable.

As for Dracula phase 1, grab the cross at the start of the level. Whenever Dracula shows up, toss a cross at his face and then backflip over his fireballs. It might take some time to get a good feel for how far from him you have to be, but once you get the timing down he's completely toothless. Also, he'll do the magma ball attack on his 4th teleport first, then on every 5th teleport after that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This boss is so ridiculously hard without magic even with save state practice. Your attack is insanely slow, your hitbox is massive, the fireballs and boss hitbox are massive, the fireballs fly all around the screen constantly hitting you over and over and knocking you back, and you do absolutely pisspoor damage considering you need to jump up twice to even get a single hit in. Even if he had half his health and you had double your health, this fight would STILL be extremely fucking difficult with no magic and harder than vast majority of NES bosses.

How the FUCK did anyone ever beat him without save states? Did they all just abuse the spin slash? Did they just use some broken strategy they read in a guide or heard from a friend? I couldn't imagine going through multiple stages with every fucking death just to get another 5 second attempt before dying.

It's literally one of the hardest bosses I've ever seen in my life (if not the hardest) and puts Contra, Castlevania, Mega Man, Ghosts N Goblins, TMNT, etc. to shame. It's the most insane difficult spike I've ever seen, because the rest of the game is hard but fair, but I'm not even exaggerating when I say this one boss alone is like 20x harder than the rest of the game combined.

The first phase of the final boss is the only one that ever gives me trouble (getting there with fire and a good amount of spirit points makes it much easier though). This phase is super easy, stay at the bottom of the screen, it's easy to dodge his fireballs down there and they will move off screen every single time, despawning them. Wait for the timing to line up so that right after you dodge his attack, you jump up on one of the pillars and then jump up again to attack him. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9560982
The PAL version of FFX isn't anything extraordinary. The squished screen and slow speed is just how every PAL conversion was when devs did not care; there are many, many, many such cases.

The reason early PS2 games like FFX and Onimusha were shat on for their 50hz only PAL version is because Europeans and other PAL regions had just tasted the Dreamcast.

Sega enforced a policy on Dreamcast: games HAD to provide both a 50 and 60hz option. So now people (and reviewers) knew, and could easily test the difference, and anything that didn't provide a 60hz option, like early PS2 games like FFX, were shat on for it (rightfully).

This ending up scaring the average publisher, as if even Squaresoft's Final Fantasy and Capcom aren't immune to being shat by reviewers for this, nobody was safe; and 60hz options on other consoles became more and more widespread.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9560770
The short answer is it caused less wear on the turbines. If your power plant is turning the generators at an RPM that amount to 60Hz on three phases, they'll last longer at 50Hz. TVs ran at 50Hz too to avoid rolling interference. There's no particular reason TVs had to run at 50Hz or 60Hz, it was just convenient. TVs could have been 48 or 72Hz to keep the film industry happy but they chose to match the electrical standards for simplicity.
At the time such decisions were being made nobody was thinking about what video games would feel like at 50fps vs. 60fps. And given how many arcade boards are actually 55-57fps it's not like 60fps is a gold standard of gaming, just a convenient common value.
Japan has a 50Hz and a 60Hz grid, they could have standardised on 50Hz for broadcasts nationwide and then all those 80s/90s games you loved would have been designed for 50fps. But because they instead matched the American standard they went with 60fps. But don't ever think it wasn't completely arbitrary.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9563681
There was a cottage industry for games shops to mod consoles to 60Hz. SEGA was usually so trivial any idiot with a soldering iron could do it. NES/SNES were much harder and required swapping out components. Usually nobody did anything about the fact that colour carrier was now at the wrong speed so it would display black & white over composite. But that was fine for consoles that supported RGB like all of SEGA's and the SNES.
But the overwhelming majority of people just didn't care. Apart from some notably bad conversions like Sonic, most PAL games were "fine" provided you weren't doing side-by-side comparisons. SF2 had major screen crunch and was noticeably slower compared to the arcade, but it was fucking SF2. You'd play that and enjoy yourself if it came with a tiny leprechaun that kicked you in the nuts the entire time. And then shortly later we got SF2 turbo which was still slower, but add an extra turbo star and it was close enough.

posts.com:
>>9564854
>Were they trying to save money by printing the label within that black border?
It's so they can print a french version, a spanish version, a german version, etc. by only changing the black areas. When you take the US box design with the memory pak, rumble pack, etc. on the artwork that means you need the source photoshop document to change it. But if it's black anyone can just black out the english version and drop in the german one. And you don't need to care if Brussels require a special legal box because you can just drop that on and not risk an angry phone call from Konami because you made them miss the release window by emailing for updated artwork.
It looks dumb in the UK because the side was just the same old logo, but it makes more sense when you consider the disparate legal and language status of greater Europe.

>>9563992
>>9563995
>>9564005
>Westerners seeked a challenge, magazines rated games based on difficulty (the higher the difficukty, the better the "longetivity" note)
That's partly true, but another reason is because of the advent of game rentals—which wasn't really a thing in Japan. If Japanese studios made games so easy that American kids were able to simply rent and beat over the weekend, they'd have no reason to purchase those games, which loses the money for the devs and publishers over time. In response, they made the American versions of games harder (and sometimes in bullshitty unfair ways) so that you'd need more than a weekend rental to beat the game. You'd actually need to buy it.

>>9565010
"rentals" is one factor but does not nearly explain it all. These days the idea that reviewers and players alike were seeking a challenge is such an alien concept, so hard to fathom, that people like to 'blame' difficulty of older games onto "rentals", as a way to say "it was intended bad design to fuck with the player", just so they can feel better about sucking or using cheats.
Yet, there are countless proofs that this mentality was real in the west, pic related being one (longetivity score, and thus the game's overall score being tied to challenge), or Japanese devs interviews explaining that very difference in mentality.
In Europe rentals weren't nearly as developed as in the US, it even quickly became banned in some countries. Yet, they still got the more difficult version of games in many cases; even when that version was a unique version (for instance Castlevania 3 which has 3 different difficulty, Europe difficulty being harder than Japanese). There is also the case of Battletoads, an European game made easier for the Japanese market.
As I was saying, rentals are one factor but do not cover it all.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9560340
In fact a bad PSU will blow up the RAM before it harms any other components in the computer. The RAM chips have small, dense dies and are very easily damaged by overvoltage while the main chips like VIC-II et al have relatively large, coarse dies that can take a fair bit of abuse. So the RAM is basically like a crumple zone in a car frame; it will get toasted first and provide a warning of imminent PSU failure.

If you happen to find a C64 with bad RAM it's more often than not a PSU fault and an indication that you'd better throw that PSU away at once (occasionally you'll come across a machine with Micron RAM chips which do a fine job of self-destructing with no help needed).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9562815
in fact the very earliest 6502s from 1975-76 were 8 um. over time MOS managed to shrink this some. the VIC-II as anon said was 5 um but also had substantially more transistors than a 6502. by the time C64 was in development, they had two main production lines running. the first was the NMOS line that couldn't do anything smaller than 5 um. there was another line that did 3 um HMOS. the large process nodes that VIC-II and SID used were outdated by the time Reagan was president but they were there and there was no point in not using them as the production line was there and the VIC-II and SID wouldn't benefit from die shrink as much as a CPU or RAM. also MOS had years of experience with the older large node NMOS process and the initial production run of VIC-II/SID in 1982 got something like 80% yields. by the time they'd moved to the plastic-shelled R2 VIC-II in early '83 it would have been better than 95% yields.

during this time Commodore was trying to go down to 2 um for CPUs and other such components. they had trouble getting it to work which resulted in the notoriously unreliable PLA and TED. a lot of these were faulty; the PLA had such low yields that they intentionally shipped C64s with defective ones to meet shipping quotas with the idea that they would be returned and swapped out for known good chips.

yes those large node processes were outdated, but since Commodore only made chips for in-house use and didn't have to be concerned with consumer demand as Intel and Motorola did, they didn't necessarily need to be aggressive about adopting the latest tech.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9563087

>during this time Commodore was trying to go down to 2 um for CPUs and other such components. they had trouble getting it to work which resulted in the notoriously unreliable PLA and TED. a lot of these were faulty; the PLA had such low yields that they intentionally shipped C64s with defective ones to meet shipping quotas with the idea that they would be returned and swapped out for known good chips.
Bil Herd claimed they had difficulty doping the wafers properly and applied too much dopant for the die size--this resulted in excessive conductivity and was visible on the die as "creeping crud" (his words). For contrast here's a section of an 8086 die. The transistors are dark purple from the dopant coating. What presumably happened with those TED chips was excess dopant oozing out onto the substrate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9563087
p. sure the actual die size of those first 6502s was 6 micrometers. in one of their early press releases MOS were promising a die shrink soon. this was accomplished in late 1976 when they went to 5 micrometers. the initial 6502s also had a non-functional ROR instruction which was fixed in the 5 micrometer version.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I think that's accurate. MOS used 6xxx P/Ns for chips using the original 5-6 um process, 7xxx for the faulty HMOS I process, and 8xxx for the "fixed" HMOS II chips.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9557841
As an EE, I say this has to be case-by-case. Throwing heat sinks around without reason can do more harm than good e.g. if they fall off and short the PCB.
Quality of IC manufacture, PCB/circuit design and tolerance to other part variation/failure are a few factors affecting IC life. True it is a waste of time for most instances, but a stoopid looking heat sink in the right place could help if a chip is poorly made, or could be subject to abnormal operating conditions. Any actual benefit, if any, will depend on the context

posts.com:

And the bad Conan the Barbarian game, that too.

from the wiki on it:

"Conan is an action game developed by Eastridge Technology and published by Mindscape. The game is actually a conversion of the computer game Myth: History in the Making for the Commodore 64. The game has also been mislabeled with the subtitle The Mysteries of Time, but this title does not exist neither in the game nor the manual. In this game, you play as the titular hero Conan, who must go through seven levels and brave the challenges of each level. There is also a bit of puzzle-solving required to get through each level, like acquiring a trident to kill the boss of the first level with, in which you must cut down a hanging skeleton, which triggers a demon holding the trident to appear.

The game was negatively received by critics due to its poor gameplay and graphics. The game was single-handedly programmed by Nick Eastridge, but the game was rushed in development by Mindscape, who forced Eastridge to complete the game quickly."

TLDR; it was rushed and was a conversion of a history game so the final boss is a pharoah monster.

Sketch bug only exists in US 1.0 for some bizarre reason, so if you're playing literally any other version you will be fine. The only other issue is the Evade glitch, but even still, it's incredibly minor and most won't even notice. Dashing was introduced in the PlayStation conversions to offset loading transitions, and it stick ever since. It cheeses timed sequences if the hack author doesn't account for it.
This is a good read for translation changes and censorship: https://legendsoflocalization.com/final-fantasy-vi/

>>9563632
Amagami sure did deserve far more respect than the fan """"translation"""" gave it. I usually don't feel sorry for EOPs but Amagami is a pretty legendary game that represents the peak of dating simulation VNs, and honestly, even those damn EOPs deserved better too.
It's a game that, to this very day, still gets hundreds if not thousands of social media posts daily, fan art, and even official stuff like the ASMR series with the same CVs from the game. There's no clear answer besides 塚原先輩 as to who the best girl is, because they're all excellent in their own way. And it's perhaps one of the easiest of its genre to get into, since you don't need to consult a guide at any point to confirm which obscure thing you have to do next, or which combination of stats you have to raise in x or y order to unlock event z at points a, b, and c of the timeline (where all 3 are easily missable).
So, how did such a respected title get such a disrespectful translation effort that spanned over a decade, only to be released in a buggy, unfinished, inaccurate state? It's a mystery. But moreover, it was so bad that it singlehandedly killed any interest in it, when it SHOULD have been opening a door for people to enjoy it instead.

I printed some sega saturn buttons and they were alright but a bit bumpy. The main thing I made is a power conditioner plastic box. Spent way longer on it than I thought for a simple box and could use another revision since dimensions may not be printed precisely. There are some gameboy cartridges on thingi verse you can try too. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
DingDongwhatchi?.. just more cookie-cutter, boring "shots-everywhere" junk to BORE me to TEARS, sorry. Last one of these new games I tried was Ikaraga... Sorry! but I learned to play color-matching games when I was two, don't need to do it anymore! Deleted THAT computer application from my Dell desktop after about 20 minutes.

R-Type, Gradius, Darius... those classics are a little more up MY alley. No TINY hitboxes to make the game look harder than it is, no half-naked japanimation cartoon girls, no gimmicky scoring to cover up the total lack of any real substance... just a little thing called good old-fashioned GAMEPLAY that seems to be forgotten nowadays... yep, I love all the super-duper powerups, and checkpoints.. yes recovery is HARD but not IMPOSSIBLE. You actually have to put in a little elbow grease to get your strength back! Something the little ones today could stand to learn from, if you ask me! They seem to want games where you can kill everything on the screen with one button press, right after inserting a coin! Instant gratification with no challenge. And personally, I usually prefer a "side-view" kind of shooter compared to a "bird's eye view" one, all those obstacles give levels a lot more personality, not such a common thing when every me-too game wants to look and play the same.

Me, I've been playing a lot of R-Type part two lately. I can only clear a couple of boards on my first man right now. I may wear out my joystick before I can manage my one quarter win! But I don't quit! What can I say, I prefer a little hard work to getting a free handout! Playing some Wings of Wor on my Sega too, and Biohazard Battle. Great vintage stuff!

As the title suggests, after you unlock a kong, you can swap between them in game with no delay, on the fly. Do you think this is a good way to revisit the game? >>9555378
That's entirely on Nintendo of America.

By the time Super Bomberman 3 released in Japan, Hudson Soft USA was closed and had to cancel localizations for Super Bonk 2 and Elfaria (possibly in collaboration with Working Designs, but Hudson would still publish)

Nintendo chose to pick up Super Bomberman 3 and Nintendo of America staff worked on the localization and game testing (there's even footage in a Japanese documentary) much like with Terranigma, they just chose to release it only in Europe.

It's not too weird, because NoE was still a subsidary of NoA and translators were really discouraged from learning Japanese directly (not that it kept them from doing it anyways, and the Japanese staff from appreciating it, and for them to eventually get their autonomy to reduce the +1 year release schedule gaps), but Nintendo of America's weird insistence on killing the SNES as soon as 1995 was something. Metal Warriors by LucasArts was supposed to be a Nintendo-published game too, and they planned an English localization of DBZ Super Butoden 2 (simply called Dragon Ball) in 1996 meant for Mexican audiences.

>>9555689
Scandinavia has its own Nintendo distribution. When Nintendo was busy getting fucked over by Atari (failed 1983 American Famicom launch as rebranded Atari, Atari intended to bury Nintendo alive by sitting on the rights all along, Nintendo headhunted some of those Atari marketing teams and tried to slowly piece together its own distribution) and Mattel/Bandai (European distribution until 1993), the Scandinavian branch was the only one actually doing its job, and even getting titles sooner than other regions.

>>9555732
Sony SCEA rejects 2D game > publisher tries to release it in Europe, if the licensing deal doesn't make it impossible to release altogether (like Capcom's Dungeons & Dragons PS1, which culminated in a standoff over Mega Man 8 and Resident Evil on the Saturn and not just a different region)
Happened a lot on the PS1.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9554771
There's been a few.
>owner of Color Dreams sees Hellraiser in theaters
>blown the fuck away
>decides that he HAS to make a game out of this somehow
>actually manages to wrangle a license for the Hellraiser IP
>it's gonna be on the NES
>also it's gonna use a special cartridge with an extra processor to make an even more advanced game
>planned sfuff like procedurally generated levels (and maybe demons?)
>some experimenting is done with the prototype cartridge they built, but the realization sets in pretty quickly that this game is going to be quite expensive to produce, meaning it's going to be quite expensive to buy
>also Color Dreams is not licensed by Nintendo so distribution and sales are never easy for them to begin with
>game gets shelved
>some years later (probably 1992 or 1993), they get the itch to try again, and they still have the license
>get the idea to license the Wolfenstein 3D engine from iD Software
>do a bit of work on this as a PC game, but then iD Software starts showing, and eventually releasing, Doom
>a game about demons and hell which would make their effort look incredibly dated and primitive in comparison
>the time for their licensing deal expires soon as well, so they decide "Fuck it." and scrap the game
>famously, Color Dreams rebrands to Wisdom Tree and focus on making Christianity themed games to sell via religious channels (where Nintendo couldn't throw any of their weight around, because they weren't distributing anything themselves around those parts)
>as Wisdom Tree, they make an unlicenses SNES game about Noah's Ark, using the Wolfenstein 3D engine they licensed
>no idea if they got any further technical assistance from iD, but supposedly the guys all thought it was incredibly funny
I don't think any pictures of gameplay or anything ever surfaced of the planned NES game, just a couple of (probably mockup) title screens. Some assets from the PC game were actually released much later on, it looks pretty preliminary.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There was another game started by another company (Magnetic Interactive or something like that) in 1995, Hellraiser : Virtual Hell. This used the Build Engine, and was supposed to be about advanced virtual reality research accidentally "reaching hell", supposedly it was meant to feature a mix of different kinds of gameplay, as well as going from 1st person to 3rd person, one of the possible bad endings was the player becoming a cenobite.
The concept for the game sounds like it was ambitious (if strangely fourth wall breaking), what few screenshots and shown off assets exist look pretty, and it was to feature some voice acting and FMV footage of Doug Bradley himself as Pinhead, recorded this during downtime from shooting Hellraiser Bloodlines.
The devs could never cope with the engine (be that for having too ambitious of a vision, or if they ran into the kind of problems Blood's devs did trying to get technical support from Ken Silverman), and in spite of having supposedly like +90% of the assets done, they think the game is shitty and unsalvageable, so they cancel it.

A couple of screenshots of empty levels were shown, some map layouts, and apparently some sprites and textures were shown at some point, in .jpeg form. I think this game was much further along, and probably had at least a somewhat playable build.

>>9558271
Here's a good article about this:
https://andrewyoderdesign.blog/2019/08/04/the-door-problem-of-combat-design/
Definitely read it despite what I'm about to say, but you will never fully solve this issue. I just fired up Plutonia's first map, pic related. I have zero reason to venture outside of this hallway. I will likely die if I go out to take on the chaingunners without the safety net of retreating further into the hall. I think you should just do what you feel you need to do if you have some kind of arena in mind. Croteam will just fucking lock doors for no reason and pit you against a horde of Mental's forces and it's great. People get really weird about these things in Doom and Quake maps, and I get it, artifice like that shows the hand of the author, but by and large I really don't give a shit.

posts.sub: How would you rank the Crazy Taxi games?
posts.com:
Seeing a lot of love for 1 but aren't the sequels just better? They include the same content + more

Also why did the PS2/GC ports get so much lower review scores? Some minor weaknesses don't account for 20% lower scores. Did Sega moneyhat reviewers back then?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: more content isn't better when it isn't sharpened to the same pointed edge that the arcade game was. it was designed to earn money by keeping games short, but you can nonetheless keep games going for a very long time through skilled play. neither crazy taxi 2 nor crazy taxi 3 were designed this way; 2's jumping was a nice idea but the maps just weren't designed as sensibly as 1's loop was to properly utilize it, and it's too easy to keep a single run going for an nauseatingly long time with no challenge involved. crazy taxi 3 just throws intelligent level design out the window entirely in favor of whatever the fuck you'd call its version of the ct1 map. the games just got less thoughtful with each release; crazy taxi 1 was a sum of its parts and adapting its pick-up-and-drop-off passengers game loop to another game doesn't work 1:1

posts.name: Anonymous

>How does HL2 stack against 1?
It's been a while since I played either game, but I remember liking them both a lot. They do very different things, however.
HL2 is definitely much more... setpiecey? than the first game. That isn't to say that the level design is bad, it's just much more linear from how I remember Half-Life's being. I don't really remember the level design being very conducive to doing a lot of exploration.
I really liked all of the weapons in HL2 though, really dug the art design, and since I played it when it was still relatively new (when the Orange Box released) I was also really into the in-engine cutscenes. I liked Episode 1 and 2 a lot, too.
The story isn't going to knock you off your feet and some of the physics "puzzles" might make you roll your eyes, but I think the game is a must-play if you already played Half-Life.

I wish I had an answer for this, but the only mods I ever played were multiplayer. Had shitloads of fun with Zombie Panic and Age of Chivalry back then.

For HL1? My personal picks would be:

Sweet Half-Life
Poke646 + It's sequel Vendetta
Azure Sheep
Point of View (AS and POV cross over with each other's main characters and are connected as mods)
They Hunger
Visitors
USS Darkstar
Afraid of Monsters Director's Cut
Cry of Fear
HL:Zombie Edition
Echoes
Residual Life + Residual Point
Absolute Redemption
INVASION (French, you can select English subtitles from an .exe that's inside the mod folder)
Someplace Else (From the creator of MINERVA, a HL2 Mod)
Paranoia (Find the standalone version that's working off of Xash3D, the HL1 Mod version requires a modified Opengl.dll which WILL trigger VAC if you connect to anything multiplayer, including non Half-Life games like CS 1.6, TFC, DOD:S, etc. Because they're in the 'Half-Life' folder rather than their own standalone folder)

>>9561485
>>9561573
HL2 is largely guys with machineguns and then also some zombies and headcrabs, featuring a section with antlions, and the occasional aircraft battles, it works overall, but considering how much more variety there was in HL1, it feels like they underdeliver somewhat. The aircraft fights in HL2 are pretty good, and they're expanded on from the sequel, but the CPs and grunts having only those goofy APCs and none of the variety of tanks and artillery from HL1, nor a fraction of machinegun nests or traps, makes them a lot less menacing and interesting, and there's no equivalent to the assassins. There's the Striders, but they're not as tough as they ought to have been (and occasionally they pretend I don't exist and leave the map).

D3 has its own problems with enemies, like an over reliance on surprise closets and teleports, many of the enemies not looking as dissimilar as they should ('gnarly grey skinned humanoid' describes too many of them at a glance), and how you're very seldom fighting anywhere BUT dim gray steel rooms and corridors (shades of Wolf3D here), but they still have old champs like Revenants, Chaingunners, Fatsos, even the Archie, and these are still pretty versatile and varied. Then add stuff like the little spiders, how Imps now leap at you and can climb at places, Zombies with chainsaws, and the Bruisers in the expansion. There's also a variety of different bosses, some which I think are a lot better than most of HL2's boss encounters (Guardian is probably iD's best boss fight).

I like both a lot, but I think there's shortcomings, more could have been learned from their predecessors, and there's outright things which one does that I wish the other also did.

Anon it's called investment. It's not like Ion Storm was spending Romero's money, it was spending Eidos' money. The way it works is you create a startup, commit some funds, find a backer (in this case Eidos), and the backer gives your startup a shitload of money. Of course, a significant portion of which goes to the people in charge of the startup, that's their personal income, it doesn't matter if the startup goes bankrupt later that doesn't change personal income. That money Eidos gave to Romero is just Romero's, he probably lost very little financially from Ion Storm failing.

Normally video game publishers are unwilling to back startups nowadays because Ion Storm isn't even unusual in how retarded and ass backwards things ended up.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9544364

Honestly I'm more impressed by someone being a video game programmer back in the day, even if they were shit at it, because it was a new field and not at all prestigious or lucrative.
People were coding stuff in their spare time at home and mostly dealing with how to implement ideas they randomly had or trying to reverse-engineer games they liked. Nothing was done for fame or virtue signaling.

I remember my dad used to buy these ZX81/Spectrum magazines that had entire pages of code in them. You would literally transcribe the code from the magazine and you got a playable game out of it.
Point being that there was a love and pursuit of discovery there and the entire gaming field was uncharted waters. Real pioneers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
As far as I am aware, every level has an exit. There are a set number of maps that have their order randomised on each playthrough, except for a few levels like Level 10, 20, 30 and maybe a couple of others that are static.
Tips for getting through the game:
- kill all enemies on every early map
- after the last enemy dies, don't hang around since they will respawn and offer 0xp, get to the stairs quickly
- test potions/scrolls/canes/rings early on to figure out their uses, so you can then stack the good ones
- be wary of late game weapons and armour, many are cursed
- don't let enemies surround you, draw them into corridors or around corners if possible so you can go 1v1
- axes suck, use spear/lance/trident etc for consistent hits
- keep a confusion scroll or two handy for late game maps, super handy for avoiding mobs completely

N64 emulation is really not that bad. In fact, it's quite good. All the must-plays and notable titles are fully playable without any but the most minor inaccuracies that you'd have to be really autistic to notice or care about, like maybe a cutscene or intro might play a bit too fast compared to real hardware, that kind of shit. Even when you delve into the less popular and unsung games, the majority also play just fine. At this point, it's only a relative handful that have noticeable issues, and even THOSE, for the most part, are still playable from start to finish. You can count on one hand the games that are still buggy enough to not be worth trying to emulate, and there's a good chance you've not even heard of them.

A lot of the early pioneering emulators were made either by edgy hacker/demoscene types or enterprising but boring old nerdy programmers. The former, however, would eventually get bored or simply move on to other things in life, while the latter were more likely to view them as products and would often monetize them. It wasn't until later, once the generation that actually grew up with the consoles from childhood, that the hobbyists and obsessive autismal types took over, which simultaneously led to massive improvements (with ample help from much higher computing power, of course) but also gave the scene the stink of constant autistic shitfits it's known for today.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9562017
DK64 is fully playable, though it does have something of an issue where physics don't work precisely as they do in real hardware due to the fact that it was programmed to accelerate your character's movement proportional to the amount of lag, so the more the game lags, the more momentum your character picks up. Due to inaccurate timings, almost all N64 emulators run the game too well with fewer framerate drops, which on paper and for the purposes of regular intended gameplay is a good thing, but it means you don't get the movement boosts you'd normally get when the game lags. This only matters if you're trying to pull off certain glitches and sequence breaks, though. It also leads to characters in the title screen demo gameplay not moving quite as expected and perhaps on certain cutscenes, but that's even more minor. Some older builds of simple64 replicated the slowdowns more accurately than every other emulator, but the latest releases regressed on this front at some point.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I don't blame them for -trying-.

But it's obvious that Dreamcast and Shenmue both share a lot of the same fundamental failings. The Dreamcast was essentially built as a final struggle against Sony's PS1 (and rumored PS2) by making something that was much more advanced, and more expensive. Audiences just didn't click with it, and Sega were left with an expensive failure that quickly got superseded. The same is basically true with Shenmue. Shenmue could've worked if it was a legit system-seller like GTA or Halo, but it wasn't.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The realization that Sega could not compete with media giants like sony, microsoft and nintendo on hardware space, and it was the correct call.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: They needed a killer app to sell the console. Didn't work but it's always a gamble.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9553232
Audiences definitely clicked with it, the DC was a massive success at first. The truth is that the PS2 was going to sweep the floor with everyone, not even Nintendo could dream to compete with the massive install base of the PS1 and the massive hype surrounding the PS2. And even though both the GC and the Xbox had excellent games and superior hardware, neither stood a chance either way. Even being weaker hardware-wise wasn't even that big of a deal for the DC as consoles in Japan have extraordinarily long life spans, both the Neo Geo AES and the SNES received games well into the late 90s. In fact, Sega could've absolutely kept supporting the DC for its lifespan (even the PS1 received games that the DC never did like THPS3), but they were so used to being a top contender that it would've been too demoralizing.

>>9553437
>In fact, Sega could've absolutely kept supporting the DC for its lifespan (even the PS1 received games that the DC never did like THPS3), but they were so used to being a top contender that it would've been too demoralizing.

No they couldn't. After the Sega Saturn, Sega wasn't in a good financial position. They invested so much money in the Saturn and barely made their money back. Sega Saturn was a big failure outside of Asia. Unlike Nintendo, Sega sells their systems at a loss. Sega makes money on game sales.

Sega honestly didn't have the cash reserves to do a launch of another console like they did for Genesis and Saturn. So Dreamcast was financed by Sega going into debt.

Sega literally used a "Credit Card" to pay for the Dreamcast. Sega ran out of money (they hit their credit card limit) around 2001. That's why they discontinued the Dreamcast. Japanese banks would not give Sega anymore loans or extend Sega's credit. They were already DEEP in the red and owed a lot of debt.

The Dreamcast did not sell like they had hoped. Sega gambled by paying for the Dreamcast with loans and credit. And it failed after 2 years.

Sega was going to declare bankruptcy if it wasn't for the Sega Miracle saving them.

>>9550794
Start with Mario, Sonic, Kirby, Donkey Kong Country, Mega Man (X or Classic is fine, but the latter tends to be harder). For Genesis there's Ristar, Dynamite Headdy, Gunstar Heroes, Vectorman, Rocket Knight series, Monster World IV, Popful Mail (technically an RPG but uses platformer controls), and The Terminator (SEGA CD version of course). Finally on TurboGrafx you've got the Bonk games and the Valis series. Some people like Castlevania but I find the early games to be kind of brutal, barring Super Castlevania IV.

For 3D platformers it's down to Mario, Banjo, Sonic, and Crash for the most part. People seem to like Jak, Sly, and Ratchet (more of a TPS/platformer hybrid) but I personally never really played those. Honestly there's so many good platformers on Super Nintendo alone you probably won't get bored with it for ages.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
A few people recommend playing Sonic at some point, and I'd agree. Sonic 3 is especially short and gives you an "easy mode" by letting you fly as Tails. (Not technically retro, but Sonic Mania also does something similar, and can be a bit more forgiving in places.)
But something to keep in mind: Sonic has a few arcade sensibilities. Sonic 1/2 have no saving, sometimes you need quick reactions to enemy placement, getting all the emeralds is hard and there are multiple routes so it encourages replays. Most big-name platformers in the years following will lean a litle closer to Mario in their structure. So if you try Sonic and find some bits aren't to your liking, don't let it put you off platformers.

The Kirby games are also tailor-made for beginners, while still usually having an enjoyable difficulty curve. Kirby's Dream Land on GB is very easy; and Kirby Super Star has an even easier, shortened remake of it with better graphics as a "first world". Adventure is also

>>9551193
https://www.mariowiki.com/Super_Mario_All-Stars has a list of all of them.

In all of them, the biggest changes are graphics/music, and the ability to save after each world.
Super Mario Bros. 3 gives you a few extra lives to start off, some very minor layout changes, and it lets you run and throw fireballs at the same time.
The Lost Levels has some more extensive changes to make it easier (saves after every level, extra lives on World 9, making access to worlds A-D easier), but it's still the hardest and cheapest game in the collection (and I think the Mario series as a whole).

Donkey Kong on whatever system. Game Boy Donkey Kong is a remake and is great.
Mario Bros. with a friend. GBA version is one of the best releases to start with.
Super Mario Bros. 'till completing easy mode.
Super Mario World.
Super Mario 64.

Sonic 1 Master System.
Sonic 2 Genesis.

Metroid.
Metroid II.
Super Metroid.

Don't play kiddy stuff like Kirby. If you need easier than what I've recommended, start with NSMB on the DS, or any New Super Mario on any system.

Also, Hollow Knight is the current best modern platformer, and Super Metroid is the best all-time, but those are harder because they are nonlinear. Start with the linear action challenges like Mario before doing maze platformers (commonly called Metroid 'vanias in honor of also the Castlevania series, which you should also play the first of on the NES).

Finally, and generally: play and make romhacks.

>Sonic might be a little bit more of a platformer, but in the sense of actually having to calculate and time jumps to avoid enemies or traps, they're not in the same league as other platformers.

Two things about this:
1. The primary complaint people have with Sonic games is that there are TOO MANY obstacles. Jumping is the only tool that Sonic has to avoid these.
2. Sonic levels have tiered level designs centered around verticality based branching. What this means is that jumps are actually so important to the experience that if you fuck them up you go to a totally different, slower part of the level.

Now let's look at a random section of adventure island: https://youtu.be/v_C-Yql7bHg?t=1216
Totally flat terrain. No branching or variance of the gameplay based on platforming skill. Corridor style level design. Sonic is more of a platformer than Adventure Island and I'd love to have you tell me otherwise. Goddamn you're a retard.

I've played most of the Final Fantasy games and the ones set in Ivalice are the best IMHO, with Final Fantasy Tactics being the greatest of them all. Seriously the game hasn't aged a bit, it's great. And funny that you should post this thread OP, because I just finished a playthrough yesterday. Probably for like the fifth time in my life. Fucking love this game.

>>9551524
Having played and finishing both the PSX and the PSP versions, I'd say PSX with a few mods.

First of all, grab Final Fantasy Tactics: The Lion War and apply it to the base game:
https://ffhacktics.com/smf/index.php?topic=12767.0

This adds all of the stuff from the PSP release into the PSX version, save for:
1. An additional character Luso (he's from Final Fantasy Tactics A2 on the DS, but lore-wise doesn't make any sense for him to be in the game anyway) who got replaced by Ashley Riot from Vagrant Story (another game set in the Ivalice region, also on PSX, in terms of the setting this is the latest entry timeline-wise) - but he's been done really tastefully.
2. One character class (Onion Knight), which kinda sucked anyway and was a major pain in the ass to master.
3. The updated translation, it sticks to the straight to the point, no bullshit script of the PSX release as opposed to going all Shakespearean on your ass. Some people will love it, others will hate it - there's two crowds of FFT fans, plenty of arguments have been made for both translations over the years.

So that's what you'd miss out on. But holy fuck do you get so much more, with Continue+ and NG+ options, three additional endgame characters you can recruit (demons) after you've finished the game for the first time, additional skills, being able to change the difficulty, stat resetting option once you've reached level 99 with a character (won't take long, trust) and would like to improve your builds, fuckloads of quality of life little patches etc. Can't go back to the vanilla FFT after this, PSX or PSP, this mod rocks

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9551524
PS1 version modded with the extra stuff the PSP version added is the best of both worlds. The reason to not use the PSP version itself is because the translation was shit and done by someone who did not understand Matsuno's writing. The original game's very blunt, matter-of-fact way of talking is in fact how the characters talk in Japanese, they don't act like they're in a stage production. Also it ran like absolute shit on an actual psp and it took like a decade for PPSSPP to come into existence, so the only way you could get it running well was by playing a modded ISO which is a non-issue now but you can just play the PS1 version.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9552687
...once you get your PSX FFT disc image patched with The Lion War, I'd also recommend downloading a patch that replaces the PSX movie clips with the anime-like ones from the PSP release:
https://ffhacktics.com/smf/index.php?topic=12945.0

Also makes the transition from the intro sequence to the start menu much smoother. So overall deffo grab it.

And then there's another patch you could consider, which adds further quality of life fixes to the game, but this one's a bit of a bitch because it could potentially introduce some bugs that weren't present in The Lion War mod originally:
https://ffhacktics.com/smf/index.php?topic=12769.0

As an example, I've had one fight constantly crashing the game in DuckStation (emulator I'm using) no matter what. I reloaded the save file before the battle using an ISO with just The Lion War mod + movie patch, finished it no problems, saved and then continued playing with the ISO that also has them QoL fixed without further crashes, but because of this I'm not sure whether I should recommend it.

As an example it allows you to send special characters (like Cloud, who someone mentioned already) on missions/errands and boost their skills that way, which is a mad fast way of going about it without grinding for hours - normally that's something you could only do with "generic" characters. And that's great, that's the real juicy bit here really, but again, not nearly as heavily tested as The Lion War and there could be bugs, full disclosure.

If you'll have trouble patching, I can upload the disc image for you in a few hours probably, but you'd have to link me to some sort of a free file uploading platform because honestly I've no clue what the fuck people use nowadays.

>>9554775
Now for some extreme cope and education about an iconic line which was altered heavily in the PSP Translation.
They changed the layout of the scene for the PSP version entirely.
Originally Delita delivers the iconic line as he looks back towards Agrias who was trying to stop him. The PSP version has him direct the line towards the princess herself since Agrias wasn't even in the same vicinity as him until shortly after the line was spoken.
https://youtu.be/ghYPElytjpY?t=13
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DpQX9vxjjIM
Therefore, there was a significant change in this line's intent between versions which, in my opinion, causes the more curt "blame yourself or god" to seem much more convincing than if he'd said the more flowery line to Agrias before running off.
The opposite holds true for the PSP version, where it seems to make considerably more sense for him to say "Tis your birth and faith that wrong you, not I."
tl;dr neither version is incorrect, and it's entirely down to the precise context of the given version of the game.
